input: Good afternoon, champ, how you holding up? Good afternoon, Doctor, I have a lot of lower back pain. Oh no, before we begin, how old are you, sir and which hand do you write with? I'm seventy five now. Right. Great, so tell me, how long have you had this lower back pain? It's been about ten days now. Have your symptoms improved at all since they began? No, they keep getting worse. Does the pain radiate into your legs? Yes, it started radiating down my right leg three days after the lower back pain began, and then the left leg three days after the right. The next day I could barely walk, the pain was so severe. Do you remember the initial date of the beginning of your low back pain? Um, it was on December third nineteen ninety five. Have you seen another doctor for this pain? Yes, I saw my local physician, um, it was on December eleventh, but he wasn't able to pinpoint what was going on. What kind of treatments did he recommend? He gave me some antiinflammatories and sent me on my way. Did you drive yourself? Yes, I did. How did the antiinflammatories work? Um, by the time I got home, I could hardly walk due to the back pain, and I had weakness in my legs. I was, however, able to feed my dogs, and I fixed myself some dinner. Was there any leg numbness? Yes. Since December eleventh. Have you seen an orthopedist for this pain? Yes, I saw one the day after my primary care physician, but my legs gave out and I fell while walking to my car because of the leg weakness and back pain. What kind of imaging studies did that orthopedist do? He did a C T and x rays of my lower back, but he didn't see anything wrong. He recommended I follow up at U I H C. The imaging was on my L S Spine.
output:
Subjective:
- Symptoms: Lower back pain, radiating pain down the right leg, then the left leg.
- Severity: Severe pain, described as "I could barely walk" and "the pain was so severe."
- Duration: Lower back pain for about ten days; radiating pain started three days after back pain began (right leg), then left leg three days later.
- Associated symptoms: Weakness in the legs, leg numbness since December eleventh.
- Relevant medical history: Saw local physician on December eleventh; received anti-inflammatory medications which were ineffective.
- Family history: Not mentioned.
- Allergies: Not mentioned.
- Other concerns: Patient expressed difficulty walking and concerns about the severity of their symptoms.

Objective:
- Physical examination findings: Not provided.
- Diagnostic test results: CT and X-rays of the lower back performed by the orthopedist, but no abnormalities were noted.
- Vital signs: Not provided.

Assessment:
- Diagnoses: Not explicitly stated, but indicated severe lower back pain with radiculopathy.
- Differential diagnoses: Not provided.
- Clinical impressions: Not explicitly stated.

Plan:
- Follow up at U I H C as recommended by the orthopedist. 
- No specific medications, treatments, or further tests mentioned in the conversation.

And yeah, if you, at all, need any resources to help you quit smoking, it's great that you're doing really well, but if you need to talk more about it or need any more resources we can provide that for you. Um, other than uh, smoking cigarettes, do you use any recreational drugs like marijuana at all? No. No. How about alcohol? Uh, I just drink on the weekends. Maybe a glass or two of wine. I was, I guess I was just worried about the cough um, it's just, I was worried that it could be COVID. Yeah, so definitely right now, any of these symptoms, like COVID can have a lot of different symptoms um, so we should definitely make sure that we, to check if you have COVID or not and we'll get a COVID swab test done for you today, and the results will come back in 24 to 48 hours. And it doesn't necessarily have to be COVID either, it can be just another virus uh, like it can be just your common cold that's been going on. So it does seem that your symptoms have gotten better. Oftentimes uh, a cough can be the last thing to go, it can take up to two weeks or more for the cough to get relieved, but it seems that you're not having any systemic symptoms like no fevers or anything else right now, so it's, it's uh, that's, that's pretty good. Great, I'm glad. Alright, yeah. Thank you. You're welcome. Take care.
output:
Subjective:
- Presenting with dry cough for 1.5 weeks
- Cough is intermittent, lasting a few seconds, and worse with smoking
- Initially had sputum production (watery) and URI symptoms (sniffles, nasal congestion, decreased sense of smell) which resolved after 2-3 days
- Cough is relieved temporarily by OTC cough syrup
- Denies current fever, chills, night sweats, SOB, sore throat, rhinorrhea, headache, chest pain, palpitations, dizziness, syncope, N/V, changes in bowel movements or urination, fatigue, loss of taste or appetite, or unintentional weight changes
- No missed work (working from home)
- No recent travel
- Daughter had flu-like illness 2 weeks ago which self-resolved
- No known sick contacts
- No exposure to dust, fumes, or animals

PMHx:
- Appendectomy 5 years ago without complications
- Allergic to penicillin (childhood rash)

FHx:
- Colon cancer (father and paternal grandfather)

SocHx:
- Lives in apartment with wife and daughter
- Smoking: currently 3-4 cigarettes/week, previously 0.5 PPD for 30 years (since age 20), gradually cutting down over past 3 years
- Alcohol: 1-2 glasses of wine on weekends
- Denies recreational drug use

Objective:
- Vitals signs: not provided
- Physical examination: not provided
- Investigations: not provided

Assessment:
- Likely post-viral cough
- COVID-19 testing pending

Plan:
- COVID-19 swab
- Self-isolation and infection control measures at home pending swab results
- Monitor symptoms and follow up if worsening or persistent cough
